title: The Cowpox of Doubt
summary:
Key ideas:
- Criticizing irrational beliefs without examining one's own irrationality can be counterproductive to the goal of rationality
- Focusing too much on obviously false beliefs can lead to a false sense of immunity to irrationality
- The "vaccination effect" in psychology can make people immune to stronger arguments against the same position if they have been presented with several weak arguments first
- This can lead to a lack of doubt and the inability to distinguish between dispassionate debates

Key learnings:
- It is important to examine our own irrational beliefs and be open-minded to other perspectives, even if they seem obviously false
- Criticizing others without examining our own assumptions can be counterproductive to the goal of rationality
- Being aware of the "vaccination effect" can help us guard against being immune to stronger arguments

Key questions:
- What are some irrational beliefs that I hold that I may not be aware of?
- How can I guard against the "vaccination effect" and remain open-minded to new information?
- In what ways can I distinguish between dispassionate debates and issues where my biases may be affecting my judgment?
